titleStmt.title: Distributed H ∞ Output-Feedback Control for Consensus of Heterogeneous Linear Multiagent Systems With Aperiodic Sampled-Data Communications

affiliation.orgName: Department of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering

analytic.title: Distributed H ∞ Output-Feedback Control for Consensus of Heterogeneous Linear Multiagent Systems With Aperiodic Sampled-Data Communications

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with the outputfeedback controller design for consensus of a class of heterogeneous linear multiagent systems with the aperiodic sampled-data measurement. Under mild assumptions that the sampling periods are taken from a given set and the agent systems are time synchronized, an equivalent switched system model is first proposed for the heterogeneous agent system with nonuniform sampling. The overall leader-following tracking control problem (LFTCP) is then formulated as the output regulation of a discrete-time switched system. By using some algebraic manipulations, the control problem under consideration is further decoupled into two control subproblems, i.e., a static outputfeedback (SOF) control problem plus a simple feedback control problem related to the communication topology. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory, some sufficient conditions are obtained for the solvability of LFTCP. In our results, the SOF controller gains are determined by solving some strict linear matrix inequalities. Finally, a simulation study on the modified Caltech multivehicle wireless testbed is presented to show the effectiveness of the proposed design method.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE last decade has witnessed the rapid development of cooperative control of multiagent systems. A group of autonomous agents can coordinate with each other via a wireless network and perform more challenging tasks than that of the single agent. The cooperative control of multiagent systems has broad applications in practice, e.g., satellite formation flying, sensor networks, surveillance and reconnaissance, smart grid, and intelligent transportation systems [1]- [3]. In the area of cooperative control, the consensus is one of the most important topics and has been widely investigated in the literature so far. For example, a general framework of a consensus of multiagent systems with fixed and switching topologies has been addressed in [4]. The same problem was also considered in [5], where a relaxed control protocol was proposed. Later, a systematic method was proposed for analyzing the consensus of linear multiagent systems in [6], where the consensus of multiagent systems with a communication topology having a spanning tree is transformed into the stability of some topology-related matrices. Very recently, the consensus-based approach has been borrowed to study the economic dispatch problem in the power industry [7], and it is shown that the power dispatch is optimal when the incremental cost of each generator achieves consensus. The consensus-based approach is also adopted for seeking the distributed Nash equilibrium and solving the optimization problems, see [8]- [11]. Some more recent works on the consensus of multiagent systems can be found in [12]- [16] and the references therein. However, most of them are concerned with state-feedback control, which may not be applicable to the scenario when some state variables are unknown or not measurable by industrial meters.

In the past few years, the output-feedback control for multiagent systems has received increasing attention, and gives rise to many publications [17]- [21]. Specifically, the distributed observer was designed in [17] for a class of second-order multiagent systems with switching topology when the velocity of the leader cannot be measured in real time. With the help of Lyapunov stability theory, it was shown that the following agents can track the active leader by the designed observer. In [18], the observer-based consensus control of multiagent systems was discussed, and a multistep algorithm was proposed to construct a reduced-order control protocol. It was shown that the multiagent systems with communication topology containing a directed spanning tree can reach consensus. In [19], the dynamic output-feedback control of general linear multiagent systems was addressed. Some necessary and sufficient conditions were presented in terms of detectability and stabilizability of the agent dynamics, graph parameter, and some matrix inequality constraints. But it is worth pointing out that the agents considered in [17]- [21] are homogeneous, which may not always be the case in reality. Very recently, the consensus of heterogeneous multiagent systems was studied in [22] based on the output-feedback control protocol. More recent works on the output-feedback control of heterogeneous multiagent systems can be found in [23]- [25]. One shall note that most of the above controller design methods are involved with high computation complexity, which may not be easily implemented in real systems. For example, five controller gains were determined in order to achieve the consensus by pure output measurement in [22], and three controller gains were designed in [23]. Moreover, it was all assumed in previous studies that the disturbances in the dynamics of the follower agents were generated by the leader, which seems to be too restrictive.

The static output-feedback (SOF) design is known as a challenging problem in control communities and has attracted considerable attention due to its great importance in practice [26]- [31]. Very recently, the distributed output feedback consensus of multiagent systems was studied in [32], and the controller design was transformed into an SOF control problem. Specifically, some modified Riccati equations were introduced for the stability and L 2 gain analysis of the closed-loop system, and in order to determine the SOF gain, some iterative algorithms were proposed such that a set of Riccatic equations are calculated repeatedly until some certain termination criterion is met. Unfortunately, there is no theoretical way to characterize the dead point, and such an iteration method is usually time consuming. Later in [33], the output-feedback-based regulation of linear heterogeneous multiagent systems was discussed, in which the SOF gain was determined by solving two linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) and one nonconvex algebraic constraint, i.e., an equality constraint. Clearly, the results in [33] are not presented in terms of strict LMIs. It is also observed that the control protocols in the above-mentioned results are designed based on the continuous-time communication with other agents, which is difficult to implement in real systems as most of the industrial meters are now designed digitally. In addition, such a continuous-time communication may not be acceptable in large-scale networked control systems due to the communication constraint or power constraint [34].

In modern industrial systems, the sampled-data-based control methodology has been extensively employed for various control purposes, e.g., the sampled-data control of spacecraft rendezvous [35] and the sampled-data control of F-18 aircraft [36]. Meanwhile, we find that the sampled-data-based approach has recently been applied onto the cooperative control of multiagent systems; see some related results in [37]- [40]. Very recently, the experimental study on consensus of two-wheeled mobile robots was performed in [41], where the sampled-data-based control protocol was designed. However, it is worth pointing out that they deal with the homogeneous agent dynamics and employ state-feedback control in [37]- [41]. To the best of our knowledge, the output-feedback-based consensus of heterogeneous linear multiagent systems with aperiodic sampled-data industrial measurement remains an open topic, which motivates the present work.

This paper presents a distributed output-feedback controller design for the leader-follower consensus of a class of heterogeneous linear multiagent systems subject to external disturbance. Unlike the existing continuous-time communication, a sampleddata case is addressed. When the sampling periods are taken from a given set, a new discrete-time switched system model is proposed for the agent system with nonuniform sampling. By using some algebraic manipulations, the control problem under consideration is decoupled into two control subproblems, i.e., an SOF control problem and a simple feedback control problem related to the communication topology. We show that the SOF gain can be determined by solving some strict LMIs. The novelty of this paper is to deal with the heterogeneous dynamics, the aperiodic sampling, and the SOF control under a unified framework. There are some difficulties in dealing with these problems, e.g., how to model the aperiodic sampling phenomenon and fully use the sampling information for controller design? How to verify the impact of sampling sequence on control performance? And how to determine the SOF controller gains by avoiding iterations? Hence, compared with the existing works in the literature, the contributions of this paper are highlighted as follows.

1) The SOF gain is determined from a set of strict LMI conditions, which is much simpler than those in [32] and [33], they can be solved easily with standard software packages such as the MATLAB LMI toolbox. Hence, our approach has lower computational complexity. 2) Only the sampled data are utilized for the controller, which is more suitable for such a networked control system. Moreover, controller gain is sampling interval dependent, which makes full use of the information on the sampling process. When the sampling process is not fully accessible, the sampling-interval-independent controller design problem is also discussed. Therefore, the proposed control protocol is more general than some existing sampled-data-based ones, for instance [37]- [41]. 3) Our leader-follower consensus problem is transformed into the output regulation of a discrete-time switched system. Compared with the SOF control of the single discrete-time switched system in [42] with the weighted l 2 condition only, a standard l 2 gain condition is obtained in this paper. We also extend the output regulation results rather than the stabilization one in [42]. Hence, the main results proposed in this paper are important additions not only to the areas of the multiagent systems, but also the area of the switched systems. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Some notations and preliminaries on the graph theory are given in Section II. The problem under consideration is formulated in Section III. The main results are presented in Section IV. The simulation example is given in Section V. Finally, some conclusions and future work are drawn in Section VI.

div.head: Notation:
div.p: The notation used throughout this paper is very standard. W T and W denote, respectively, the transpose and the induced norm of any square matrix W . W > 0 denotes a positive-definite matrix W and I represents the identity matrix with compatible dimensions. Let R n denote the n-dimensional Euclidean space. R m × n is the set of all m × n real matrices. L 2 [0, + ∞) is the space of integrable infinite sequence and l 2 [0, + ∞) is the space of summable sequence. The symbol "*" is used in some matrix expressions to represent the symmetric terms and the symbol "⊗" is introduced as a Kronecker product. We use diag{•} for a block-diagonal matrix. The term He (W ) represents He (W ) = W + W T . Matrices are of compatible dimensions if they are not defined explicitly.

Here, some basic knowledge about graph theory is given. A directed graph G is a pair (V , Z), where V = {v 1 , . . . , v N } is a set of nodes, and Z ⊆ V × V is a set of edges. For an edge (v i , v j ), node v i is called the parent node and v j is the child node. A directed graph contains a directed spanning tree if there exists a node called the root, such that the node has a directed path to every other node in the graph. Moreover, the root has no parent node. In graph theory, a path in a graph is a finite or infinite sequence of edges, which connect a sequence of vertices.

div.head: The adjacency matrix
div.formula: A = [a pq ] ∈ R N × N associated with the directed graph G is defined by a pq = 1 if (v p , v q ) ∈ V and a ij = 0 otherwise. The Laplacian matrix L = [l ij ] ∈ R N × N is defined as l ii = j =i a ij and l ij = -a ij , i = j.
div.p: In this paper, we assume that the graph is undirected, and at least one follower has the information of the leader node at each sampling time instant.

div.head: III. PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: Consider a set of N heterogeneous agents, which are indexed by i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and represented by their continuous-time linear time-invariant model
div.formula: ẋi (t) = A i x i (t) + B i u i (t) + D i ω i (t) y i (t) = C i x i (t)(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i (t) ∈ R n i , u i (t) ∈ R p i , ω i (t) ∈ R m i
div.p: , and y i (t) ∈ R q are the state, control input, disturbance, and the output, respectively. A i , B i , D i , and C i are some constant matrices. In this paper, the leader's dynamics are given by
where ς 0 (t) ∈ R m and y 0 (t) ∈ R q are the state and output of the leader, respectively, S ∈ R m × m and R ∈ R q × m are two constant matrices.

It is worth pointing out that the leader's dynamic is not controllable here, which can be found in many tracking systems, e.g., a group of mobile robots are deployed to monitor the evil robot invading into some desired fields. The controlled leader case is beyond the scope of this paper. We now make the following assumptions for our consensus problem.
Assumption 1: The real parts of the eigenvalues of matrix S are nonnegative.
Assumption 2: The matrix pairs (A i , B i ) and (A i , C i ) are stabilizable and detectable, respectively, for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N.
Assumption 3: All the agents are time synchronized with the same sampling period at each time instant.
Assumption 4: The communication graph contains a spanning tree with the leader as its root.

Remark 1: Assumption 1 is made to avoid the trivial case since it will not affect the dynamic behavior of the closed-loop system when the eigenvalues of matrix S are of negative real part. Note that the main results are also valid if the eigenvalues of matrix S are of negative part; see the discussions in [24]. Assumption 2 is a standard assumption for solvability of the output-feedback control problem. Assumption 3 is a common assumption for consensus of multiagent systems by sampled data, which can also be found in [37]- [41]. Specifically, a real experiment testbed has been developed for consensus of two-wheeled mobile robots in [41], where all robots are time synchronized and the sampling periods of robots are varying equally. There may be the cases when output and controller are sampled and updated at different rates, respectively, but here we only discuss the case when output and control signals are sampled and updated at the same rate, i.e., once the output of agent is sampled, it will be utilized directly for the computing controller. Assumption 4 is necessary for the leader-following tracking control problem, which can also be found in [24].

In cooperative control of many practical multiagents, e.g., robotics, it usually communicates with its neighbors by using a wireless network. It is well known that frequent communication would lead to high communication traffic, which then increases the occurrence of time delays or dropouts of transmitted packets. A good way to alleviate this is to reduce the sampling rate and/or the transmission rate. In this paper, the sampled-databased control approach is used for the control update. Suppose that all followers and the leader are clock synchronized and during each sampling period, the followers use the available sampled data to update its control input. Let the sampling period be τ k = t k +1t k , where t k is the sampling time instant. In this paper, we assume that the sampling period τ k only takes a value from Φ = {T 1 , T 2 , . . . , T m }, where T j , j = 1, 2, . . . , m are some allowable sampling periods. m > 0 is a positive scalar.
Define
div.formula: x i [k] = x i (t k ), u i [k] = u i (t k ), ω i [k] = ω i (t k ), y i [k] = y i (t k ), y 0 [k] = y 0 (t k ), ς 0 [k] = ς 0 (t k ).
div.p: Then, under a zero-order hold device with the sampling period τ k , the converted discrete-time models of (1) and ( 2) are given, respectively, by
div.formula: x i [k + 1] = Âi (τ k ) x i [k] + Bi (τ k ) u i [k] + Di (τ k ) ω i [k] y i [k] = C i x i [k](3)
div.p: and
where
div.formula: Âi (τ k ) = e A i τ k , Bi (τ k ) = τ k 0 e A i s B i ds, Di (τ k ) = τ k
div.p: 0 e A i s D i ds, and Ŝ (τ k ) = e S τ k . Since the values of matrices Âi (τ k ) , Bi (τ k ) , Di (τ k ), and Ŝ (τ k ) are directly dependent on τ (k), where τ k ∈ Φ, we now introduce a switching signal ρ (k) ∈ Φ = {1, 2, . . . , m}, such that
div.formula: x i [k + 1] = A i,ρ(k ) x i [k] + B i,ρ(k ) u i [k] + D i,ρ(k ) ω i [k] y i [k] = C i x i [k](5)
div.p: and
where
div.formula: A i,ρ(k ) , B i,ρ(k ) , D i,ρ(k )
div.p: , and S ρ(k ) are the possible realizations of Âi (τ k ) , Bi (τ k ) , Di (τ k ), and Ŝ (τ k ), respectively. For the switching signal ρ(k), the switching time sequence is defined as

, and the holding time between [k l , k l+1 ] is the dwell time of the sth engaged subsystem, i.e., ρ(k) = s. Based on the above equivalent discrete-time models of system (1) and ( 2), we now consider the following control protocol:
div.formula: ς i [k + 1] = S ρ(k ) ς i [k] + H ρ(k ) Σ ij [k] u i [k] = K i,ρ(k ) (y i [k] -C i Π i ς i [k]) + Γ i,ρ(k ) ς i [k](7)
div.p: where
div.formula: Σ ij [k] = j ∈V i a ij ς ij [k] + g i ς i0 [k], ς ij [k] = ς j [k] - ς i [k], ς i0 [k] = ς 0 [k] -ς i [k],
div.p: V i are the neighboring nodes of node i, g i ≥ 0 is the pinning gain of protocol i. More specifically, g i > 0 if and only if the ith follower can access to leader's information; otherwise g i = 0. K i,ρ(k ) and H ρ(k ) are controller gains to be determined. Motivated by the recent results on the output regulation problem in [43] and [44], Π i and Γ i,ρ(k ) in ( 7) are assumed to be the solutions to the following regulation equations:
div.formula: A i,ρ(k ) Π i + B i,ρ(k ) Γ i,ρ(k ) = Π i S ρ(k ) C i Π i = R, ρ (k) ∈ {1, 2, . . . , m}(8)
div.p: where the solvability of regulation function ( 8) is guaranteed if
div.formula: rank A i -λI B i C i 0 = n i + p i , ∀λ ∈ σ(S)
div.p: , with σ(S) being the spectrum of S; see [22] for more details.
Remark 2: The control protocol proposed in [22] is described as
div.formula: u i = K 1i ξ i + K 2i η i ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ξi ηi = A i E i 0 S ξ i η i + B i 0 u i + L 1i L 2i C m i ξ i + D m i u i +F m i η i -y m i , i = 1, . . . , l ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ ξi = A i ξ i + B i u i + E i η i + L i C m i ξ i + D m i u i +F m i η i -y m i ηi = Sη i + μ N j =1 a ij (η j -η i ), i = l + 1, . . . , N
div.p: where K 1i , K 1i , L 1i , L 2i , and L 2i are the gains to be determined.
The control protocol proposed in [23] is described as
div.formula: lu i = K 1i x i + K 2i z i żi = A 0 z i + k 0 a i0 (t)(v -z i ), i ∈ V r żi = A 0 z i + n j =1 a ij (t)k ij (t)(z j -z i ), i ∈ V n -r
div.p: where K 1i , K 2i , and k 0 are the controller gains to be designed. Compared with these two control protocols, the controller (7) has fewer controller gains. The most important feature is that only the discrete-time sampled data are used rather than the continuous-time data in these results. We shall also point out that the protocol ( 7) is a dynamical controller, and our future attention will be focused on designing a static controller to reduce the implementation complexity in (7).
Define the output error as e i = y iy 0 , and also denote the following error signal:
div.formula: ε i [k] = x i [k] -Π i ς i [k] η i [k] = ς i [k] -ς 0 [k] . (9
div.p: Let
div.formula: ε [k] = ε T 1 [k] , . . . , ε T N [k] T η [k] = η T 1 [k] , . . . , η T N [k] T x [k] = ε T [k] , η T [k] T G = diag{g 1 , . . . , g N } A ρ(k ) = diag{A 1,ρ(k ) , . . . , A N ,ρ(k ) } B ρ(k ) = diag{B 1,ρ(k ) , . . . , B N ,ρ(k ) } D ρ(k ) = diag{D 1,ρ(k ) , . . . , D N ,ρ(k ) } C = diag{C 1 , . . . , C N }Π = diag{Π 1 , . . . , Π N } K ρ(k ) = diag{K 1,ρ(k ) , . . . , K N ,ρ(k ) } ω = ω T 1 , . . . , ω T N T R c = I N ⊗ R Ãρ(k) = A ρ(k ) + B ρ(k ) K ρ(k ) C.
div.p: Then, we have the following closed-loop system:
div.formula: x [k + 1] = A c (ρ(k)) x [k] + D c (ρ(k)) ω [k] e [k] = C c x [k](10)
div.p: where
div.formula: A c (ρ(k)) = Ãρ(k) (L + G) ⊗ ΠH ρ(k ) 0 I N ⊗ S ρ(k ) -(L + G) ⊗ H ρ(k ) D c (ρ(k)) = D ρ(k ) 0 , C c = C R c .
div.p: Similar to the control performance definition of H ∞ pinning synchronization of complex networks with aperiodic sampleddata communication in [38], we formulate our control problem as follows.

Problem 1: Design the output-feedback controller (7) such that for k → +∞, the error vector meets e i [k] → 0, when ω i [k] = 0, and under zero initial conditions, i.e., ), where γ is a positive scalar.
div.formula: ε i [k 0 ] = 0, η i [k 0 ] = 0, such that e i [k] ≤ γ ω i [k] for all ω i [k] ∈ l 2 [0, ∞

div.head: IV. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we show how to analyze the closed-loop system (10) and how to determine the controller gains.
Theorem 1: Problem 1 is solvable if the following N systems:
div.formula: εi [k + 1] = Ãi,ρ(k) εi [k] + D i,ρ(k ) ωi [k] e i [k] = C i εi [k] , i = 1, . . . , N(11)
div.p: are simultaneously exponentially stable when the disturbance is zero and under the zero initial conditions, all of these N systems have a prescribed H ∞ performance level γ i , and the following
div.formula: N systems ηi [k + 1] = S ρ(k ) -λ i H ρ(k ) ηi [k] , i = 1, . . . , N(12)

div.formula: Āc (ρ(k)) = Ãρ(k) (L + G) T -1 ⊗ ΠH ρ(k ) 0 I N ⊗ S ρ(k ) -Λ ⊗ H ρ(k ) D c (ρ(k)) = D ρ(k ) 0 , Cc = C T -1 ⊗ R c .
div.p: Note that from (14), one can conclude
div.formula: xi [k + 1] = Āi,c (ρ(k)) xi [k] + D i,c (ρ(k)) ω i [k] e i [k] = C i,c xi [k](15)
div.p: where
div.formula: xi [k] = εi [k] ηi [k] Āi,c (ρ(k)) = Ãi,ρ(k) M 0 S ρ(k ) -λ i H ρ(k ) D i,c (ρ(k)) = D i,ρ(k ) 0 C i,c = C i N .
div.p: Since the input does not affect ηi [k], then one can choose a suitable H ρ(k ) such that S ρ(k ) -λ i H ρ(k ) is stable, then M and N do not appear in the transfer function from ω i to e i . Thus, one can see that if system ( 15) is exponentially stable with a prescribed H ∞ performance level γ i and system ( 10) is exponentially stable, then the original error system (10) is exponentially stable with H ∞ performance level γ = max{γ i }.

We are now going to discuss the stability and l 2 gain of systems ( 11) and (12), which are essentially an SOF control problem and a simple feedback control problem. It follows from (11) and ( 12) that the dynamics of these two systems are also determined by the switching signal ρ(k); a natural question is how such a switching signal can affect the system dynamics? Before the discussion of this problem, the following definition is first introduced: Definition 1: [45] For any k > k 0 , and any switching signal ρ(τ ), k 0 ≤ τ ≤ k, let N ρ denote the number of switching of ρ(τ ) over (k 0 , k). If N ρ ≤ N 0 + (kk 0 )/T a holds for T a > 0 and N 0 ≥ 0, then T a is called the average dwell time and N 0 is the chatter bound.

Definition 1 gives some basic information on the so-called average dwell time scheme, which will be used for the stability and l 2 gain analysis of systems ( 11) and ( 12). We will show in the subsequent analysis that the average dwell time switching scheme can help establish the relation between the sampling period switching and the control performance. For the subsequent analysis, we will choose N 0 = 0 as in [46]- [51].
Theorem 2: For given scalars 0 < α i,s < 1, μ i > 1, τ i > 0, the system ( 11) is exponentially stable and with a prescribed

div.p: Proof: We first address the exponential stability and l 2 gain analysis of system (11). Here, the following piecewise Lyapunov function is constructed:
div.formula: V i,ρ(k ) [k] = εT i [k] P -1 i,ρ(k ) εi [k] . (21
div.p: Due to the fact that when k ∈ [k l , k l+1 ), the activated subsystem may not be the lth subsystem. So, without loss of generality, supposing that the sth subsystem is currently engaged when k ∈ [k l , k l+1 ), i.e., ρ (k ) = s, then

div.p: which is the same as (16). Clearly, (23) implies that
div.formula: V i,s [k + 1] -α i,s V i,s [k] + e T i [k] e i [k] -τ 2 i ωT i [k] ωi [k] < 0. (24
div.p: For the switching time instant
div.formula: k 0 < k 1 < • • • < k l < • • • , one has V i,s [k] ≤ α i,s k -k l V i,l [k l ] - k -1 q =k l α i,l k -q -1 Υ [q] (25
div.p: where
div.formula: Υ [k] = e T i [k] e i [k] -τ 2 ωT i [k] ωi [k].
div.p: It follows from ( 17) and ( 25) that
div.formula: V i,ρ(k l ) [k] ≤ α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) V i,ρ(k l ) [k l ] - k -1 q =k l α k -q -1 i,ρ(k l ) {Υ [q]} ≤ α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) μ i V i,ρ(k l -1 ) [k l ] - k -1 q =k l α k -q -1 i,ρ(k l ) {Υ [q]} ≤ α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) μ i α k l -k l -1 i,ρ(k l -1 ) V i,ρ[k l -1 ] (k l-1 ) -α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) μ i ⎡ ⎣ k l -1 q =k l -1 α k -q -1 i,ρ(k l -1 ) {Υ [q]} ⎤ ⎦ - k -1 q =k l α k -q -1 i,ρ(k l ) {Υ [q]} ≤ • • • ≤ μ N ρ (k 0 ,k ) i α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) α k l -k l -1 i,ρ(k l -1 ) • • • α k 1 -k 0 i,ρ(k 0 ) × V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ] -Θ(Υ)(26)
div.p: where
div.formula: Θ(Υ) = μ N ρ (k 0 ,k -1) i α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) l-1 q =1 α k q + 1 -k q i,ρ(k q ) × k 1 -1 q =k 0 α k 1 -1-q i,ρ(k 0 ) {Υ [q]} + μ N ρ (k 0 ,k -1)-1 i α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) × l-1 q =2 α k j + 1 -k j i,ρ(k j ) k 2 -1 q =k 1 α k 2 -1-q i,ρ(k 1 ) {Υ [q]} + • • • + μ 0 i k -1 q =k l α k -1-q i,ρ(k l ) {Υ [q]}.
div.p: Now, we analyze the exponential stability of system (11) with ωi (k) = 0, then (26) leads to
div.formula: V i,ρ(k l ) [k] ≤ μ N ρ (k 0 ,k ) i α k -k l i,ρ(k l ) α k l -k l -1 i,ρ(k l -1 ) • • • α k 1 -k 0 i,ρ(k 0 ) V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ] ≤ μ N ρ (k 0 ,k ) i α k -k 0 max V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ] ≤ μ 1/T a α max k -k 0 V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ] = χ 2(k -k 0 ) V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ](27)
div.p: where χ = α max μ 1/T a . Furthermore, by combining ( 21) and (27), it is easy to see that there exist two positive scalars ϕ 1 > 0 and
div.formula: ϕ 2 > 0, such that εi [k] 2 ≤ ϕ 2 ϕ 1 χ 2(k -k 0 ) εi [k 0 ] 2 .
div.p: According to condition (18), one can readily obtain χ < 1. Thus, system ( 11) is exponentially stable.
We now discuss the H ∞ performance level. Under zero initial condition, i.e., V i,ρ(k 0 ) [k 0 ] = 0, and by the fact that
div.formula: V i,ρ(k l ) [k] ≥ 0, then it follows from (26) that Θ(Υ) ≤ 0. By choosing α min = min s∈ Φ {α i,s } and α max = max s∈ Φ {α i,s }, it is easy to see that k -1 q =k 0 μ N ρ (q,k-1) i α k -q -1 min e T i [q] e i [q] ≤ τ 2 i k -1 q =k 0 μ N ρ (q,k-1) i α k -q -1 max ωT i [q] ωi [q] . (28
div.p: By resorting to the average dwell time condition (18), it is easy to see

div.p: < -ln α ln μ i . Based on the assumption that μ i > 1, we can easily obtain ln μ N ρ (q,k-1) i < ln α -(k -q -1) and 1) . Then, it can be readily seen that
div.formula: 1 < μ N ρ (q,k-1) i < α -(k -q -
k -1 q =k 0 α k -q -1 min e T i [q] e i [q] < τ 2 i k -1 q =k 0 (α max /α) k -q -1 α k -q -1 ωT i [q] ωi [q] . (29
div.p: Summing ( 29) from k = k 0 + 1 to k = ∞ and changing the order of summation yield
div.formula: +∞ q =k 0 e T i [q] e i [q] +∞ k =q +1 α k -q -1 min < τ 2 i +∞ q =k 0 ωT i [q] ωi [q] +∞ k =q +1 (α max /α) k -q -1 . (30
div.p: Due to the fact that
div.formula: +∞ k =q +1 α k -q -1 min = 1 1-α m in and +∞ k =q +1 (α max /α) k -q -1 = 1 1-(α m a x /α) , we have +∞ q =k 0 e T i [q] e i [q] < γ 2 i +∞ q =k 0 ωT i [q] ωi [q](31)
div.p: where
div.formula: γ i = τ 1-α m in
div.p: 1-α m a x /α . Now, we can conclude that the closed-loop system ( 11) is exponentially stable and achieves a prescribed H ∞ performance level γ i . By using the similar analysis method, it is easy to show that the system (12) is exponentially stable if the inequalities ( 18)-( 20) are satisfied.

Remark 3: During the derivation of the exponential stability of systems (11) and (12), we have shown that the exponential decay rate χ is critically dependent on the average dwell time T a . Hence, for a desired control performance, the switching law cannot be assigned arbitrarily.

So far, we have given some sufficient conditions for the exponential stability and l 2 gain analysis of system (11) and (12). But the controller gain is still difficult to determine due to the coexistence of P i,s and P -1 i,s . Before the main results, we first introduce the following lemma:
Lemma 1: For any matrices T , M, N , and W with appropriate dimensions, the inequality
div.formula: T + W T M T + MW < 0(32)
div.p: holds if the following inequality:
div.formula: T * M T + N W -N -N T < 0(33)
div.p: is true.
Proof: Left and right multiplying (33) by the full row rank matrix I W T and its transpose, respectively, yields (32).
Based on the above lemma, we are in a position to present a controller gain design.
Theorem 3: For given scalars 0 < α i,s < 1,
div.formula: μ i > 1, τ i > 0, Problem 1 is solvable if there exist matrices P i,s = P T i,s > 0, Q s = Q T s > 0, G i,s , L i,s , U i,s
div.p: , such that the average dwell time condition (18) and the following inequalities:
div.formula: P i,t ≤ μ i P i,s(36)
Qs ≤ μ i Qt(37)
div.p: are simultaneously satisfied for all s, t ∈ Φ, s = t; i = 1, 2, . . . , N . Then, the SOF controller gains are determined by
div.formula: K i,s = L i,s U -1 i,s and H s = Q-1 s Hs . The matrix in (34) is given by Ψ 11 = -G i,s -G T i,s + α -1 i,s P i,s , Ψ 31 = A i,s G i,s + B i,s L i,s F , Ψ 32 = D i,s , Ψ 41 = C i G i,s , Ψ 51 = C i G i,s - U i,s F , Ψ 53 = N T i,s L T i,s B T i,s , Ψ 55 = -U i,s N i,s -N T i,s U T i,s
div.p: where F and N i,s are free matrices that can be preselected by designers.
Proof: First, left and right multiplying ( 16) by diag{G T i,s , I, I, I} and its transpose, respectively, one sees that ( 16) is equivalent to
div.formula: ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ -α i,s G T i,s P -1 i,s G i,s * * * 0 -τ 2 i I * * A i,s G i,s + B i,s K i,s C i G i,s D i,s -P i,s * C i G i,s 0 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ < 0.(38)
div.p: By the basic inequality
div.formula: -V T Q -1 V ≤ -V -V T + Q, it
div.p: is easy to verify that (38) holds if the following inequality holds:
div.formula: ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ -G i,s -G T i,s + α -1 i,s P i,s * * * 0 -τ 2 i I * * A i,s G i,s + B i,s K i,s C i G i,s D i,s -P i,s * C i G i,s 0 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ < 0.(39)
div.p: Then, we rewrite inequality (34) as
where
div.formula: Σ 1 = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ -G i,s -G T i,s + α -1 i,s P i,s * * * 0 -τ 2 i I * * A i,s G i,s + B i,s L i,s F D i,s -P i,s * C i G i,s 0 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ Σ 2 = N T i,s L T i,s B T i,s 0 0 I 0 + U i,s N i,s N -1 i,s U -1 i,s (C i G i,s -U i,s F ) I 0 0 0 Σ 3 = -U i,s N i,s -N T i,s U T i,s . Now, denote T = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ -G i,s -G T is + α -1 i,s P i,s * * * 0 -τ 2 i I * * A i,s G i,s + B i,s L i,s F D i,s -P i,s * C i G i,s 0 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ W = N -1 i,s U -1 i,s (C i G i,s -U i,s F ) I 0 0 0 M = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ 0 0 I 0 ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ B i,s L i,s N i,s , N = U i,s N i,s .
div.p: By using Lemma 1 on (40), we obtain
div.formula: T + W T M T + MW = Σ 1 + He Î ΨL i,s U -1 i,s (C i G i,s -U i,s F ) Ĩ = Σ1 + He Î Ψ Ĩ < 0(41)
div.p: where
div.formula: Σ1 = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ -G i,s -G T i,s + α -1 i,s P i,s * * * 0 -τ 2 i I * * A i,s G i,s D i,s -P i,s * C i G i,s 0 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ Ĩ = I 0 0 0 , Î = 0 0 I 0 T Ψ = B i,s L i,s U -1 i,s ((C i G i,s -U i,s F ) + U i,s F ) .
div.p: Let K i,s = L i,s U -1 i,s , one can see that (41) becomes
div.formula: Σ1 + He ÎB i,s K is C i G is Ĩ < 0. (42
div.p: By further manipulation, it is seen that ( 42) is exactly (39), which implies that ( 16) is true. On the other hand, denote Qs = Q -1 s , left and right multiplying (19) by diag I, QT s and its transpose, respectively, ( 19) is equivalent to
div.formula: -α i,s Qs * Qs (S s -λ i H s ) -Qs < 0.(43)
div.p: Set Hs = Qs H s , we obtain (35). Remark 4: In Theorem 3, the matrices F and N i,s are slack variables that can be chosen by designers. By doing so, a strict LMI-based solution is obtained to calculate the controller gain.

The above strict LMIs in ( 34)-( 37) can be effectively solved by existing numerical software, e.g., MATLAB LMI Toolbox. Hence, our main results have less computation complexity than that of [32] and [33]. One possible future work is how to choose the optimal values for matrices F and N i,s to reduce the design conservatism.

Remark 5: It is necessary to give some guidelines on choosing α i,s and μ i . It is easy to see that the inequalities (34) and (35) are easier to hold for larger α i,s . Similarly, the inequalities (36) and (37) are easier to hold for a larger μ i . In contrast, the required average dwell time condition (18) may become more difficult to hold for large α i,s and μ i . So, one should first choose some larger α i,s such that the inequalities (34) and (35) are feasible, then choose a smaller μ i such that the inequalities (36) and (37) are feasible. At the same time, one needs to check the required average dwell time condition (18) until it is satisfied.

Remark 6: We have provided a sampling-interval-dependent control design algorithm in the previous sections. The implementation of such a mode-dependent controller requires highperformance hardware to capture the variation of sampling periods. When such high-performance hardware is not available, one may resort to the sampling-interval-independent control protocol. In this scenario, one may choose L i and U i to determine the controller gain K i . To determine the controller gain H, (35) should be replaced by
div.formula: -Ḡ -ḠT + α i,s Q s * S s Ḡ -λ i H -Q s < 0
div.p: where Ḡ is an unknown matrix with appropriate dimension. Furthermore, (37) should also be replaced by Q s ≤ μQ t . Then, the controller gain H is computed by H = H Ḡ-1 .

div.head: V. ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLE
div.p: In the past few decades, the mobile robots have received much research attention due to their applications onto universe exploration, ocean development, atomic energy, and other fields such as factory automation, construction, mining, military, and agricultural services. In parallel with the theoretical research on the mobile robots, many platforms have also been developed, e.g., the sensor-network-based target tracking testbed at Zhejiang University of Technology, China [52] and the coordination testbed at Utah State University, USA [53]. Specifically, the textbed in the COVEN Laboratory at Utah State University includes five Amigobots and two P3-DX from the ActivMedia Robotics; see in [53]. This testbed has been used in [53] for the validation of the containment control of multiagent systems, in which the motion of autonomous vehicle was modeled as double-integrator dynamics. Recently, the mathematical model of the autonomous vehicle was modified in [54] by considering the different types of actuators. Then, it was shown that the internal model principle is a necessary and sufficient condition for the output regulation problem. Since our problem is similar to the one in [54], the mathematical model of the vehicle in [54] is borrowed for the simulation purpose. As in [54], the position tracking of multiple wheeled mobile robots is our concern. For simplicity but without loss of generality, the simulation testbed includes one leader and five followers, and the dynamics of each follower is modeled by (1) [54] with

where a i , b i , c i , d i , and e i are some constants. The first two state components are known as the position and velocity, respectively. The third state component is regarded as the actuator state. The constant a i presents the speed of the actuator, whereas the constants b i and c i are the gains. If d i > 0, the actuator is affected by the velocity, which will create an internal feedback loop. The disturbance weighting parameter is e i . More descriptions on the above mathematical modeling can be found in [54].
The leader's dynamic is modeled by (2) with

For simulation purposes, we choose It follows from this example that only the position information of vehicle is utilized for control update. In reality, the position information can be obtained by equipment such as GPS and ultra wideband positioning systems, while most of them are the digitized devices. From an implementation point of view, in this example each follower only uses the sampled data for control law design. The interaction of agent systems is shown in Fig. 1. Without loss of generality, the sampling process in the simulation is nonuniform and the sampling period is taken from Φ = {0.1 s, 0.2 s}. Moreover, the sampling period is switching periodically with the period of five time steps. The matrix pair of (Π i , Γ i,s ) in ( 8) can be determined as

It is noted that Π i , i = 1, 2, . . . , 5 are identical since all the outputs of followers are the same. Meanwhile, the values of Γ i,s are not dependent on the sampling modes, which may be induced possibly by the fact that both sides of the first equation in (8) Based on the chosen parameters for α i,1 , α i,2 , and μ i , we then choose α = 0.98. For such a scalar α, the average dwell time condition ( 18) is satisfied. Thus, the obtained H ∞ performance level is γ = 11.0680. Now supposing the disturbance is zero, and choosing random initial conditions for ς 0 , x i and zero in initial conditions for ς i , the trajectories of the position of the leader and followers are shown in Fig. 2, and the trajectories of the position errors e i are depicted in Fig. 3. One can see that the error dynamics are stable. We now choose the disturbance signal as ω i = i * sin(0.1t)e -0.1t , i = 1, 2, . . . , 5, and the initial conditions of x i and ς i are x i = 1 2 3 T and ς i = ς 0 = 1 2 T , i = 1, 2, . . . , 5. The simulation results are shown in Fig. 4, which shows that the position tracking error dynamic is regulated very well when the disturbance vanishes.

When the disturbance is taken as ω i = i * sin(t), the simulation results are depicted in Fig. 5. In this scenario, the tracking error will not decay to zero since the disturbance will affect the dynamics of the follower persistently. A similar conclusion can be found in the H ∞ synchronization control of complex networks in [38]. By simple calculation, the practical H ∞ performance levels are γ * 1 = 0.2638, γ * 2 = 0.4968, γ * 3 = 0.1218, γ * 4 = 0.3475, and γ * 5 = 0.3468, which are all smaller than the optimal one. Hence, the tracking performance is still guaranteed even when the disturbance does not vanish.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: We studied the output-feedback consensus control for a class of heterogeneous linear multiagent systems in the presence of disturbance and nonuniform sampling processes. It was shown that the considered problem was transformed into the output tracking problem of a discrete-time switched system. By using the Lyapunov stability theory, some sufficient conditions were obtained that guarantee the solvability of the problem. Then, with the help of some useful matrix manipulations, the SOF controller gains were determined by solving a set of strict LMIs. Finally, a simulation study on the position tracking of autonomous vehicles was performed that showed the effectiveness of the results. In the near future, the other network-induced uncertainties, such as packet dropouts, transmission delays, and switching topology [55], [56], will be addressed. On the other hand, the detailed application of the leader-following tracking system to the vehicle platooning in the intelligent transportation systems will also be considered, and the novel results in [57] and [58] may provide some insights for this extension.

By choosing α i,1 = 0.95, α i,2 = 0.97, τ i = 5, μ i = 1.1, F = 1 0 0 , and N i,s = 20, we have the following feasible solutions from Theorem 3: K 11 = -4.5509, K 21 = -1.3921, K 31 = -2.2755, K 41 = -4.7677, K 51 = -2.3839, K 12 = -2.3583, K 22 = -0.7211, K 32 = -1.1792, K 42 = -2.4712, K 52 = -1.2356
